questions.text: A 78-year-old man presented to the emergency department with weakness on the left side that had developed 90 minutes earlier. An ischemic stroke in the territory of the right middle cerebral artery was diagnosed, and treatment was initiated. After some time, the examination showed the following change in the patient’s tongue. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tissue plasminogen activator-associated angioedema Orolingual angioedema is a known potential adverse effect of intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA). The swelling can be asymmetric at first ( Hemi Orolingual Angioedema )and can develop in a location contralateral to the ischemic lesion following a stroke. The mechanism is incompletely understood could be due to increase in plasmin leading to increased bradykinin formation and increased degranulation of mast cell releasing histamine . Treatment in this case included intravenous antihistamines and glucocorticoids , without the need for advanced airway management.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Lingual artery thrombosis- this could be seen secondary to traumatic injury during Road traffic accident or iatrogenic after oral cavity /tonsil surgery. And Recombinant Tissue Plasminogen Activator (rtPA) is a thrombolytic . Hence, this option is ruled out. Option C. Lingual dystonia -is a rare hyperkinetic movement disorder ,often occurring secondary to drugs like Neuroleptics,Antipsychotics,Antiemetics. Option D. Unilateral hypoglossal nerve palsy - can result from tumors/stroke/neurological diseases and not secondary to use of Recombinant Tissue Plasminogen Activator (rtPA).

questions.text: An obese 45-year-old male, with known hyperlipidaemia and peripheral vascular disease, presents with a right parietal ischaemic stroke. He reports trouble sleeping and laying flat at night that began after a flu-like illness 3 months ago and reports some exertional dyspnoea. Which of the following investigations is most likely to find the cause of the stroke?

options.label: C
options.text: Magnetic resonance imaging / Magnetic resonance angiography(MRI/MRA)

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Echocardiogram The underlying diagnosis is a viral myocarditis precipitating a dilated cardiomyopathy and causing a cardioembolic stroke and Echocardiogram can find out the cause of cardioembolic stroke.

Highyeild:

Cardioembolism is responsible for ~20% of all ischemic strokes. Stroke caused by heart disease is primarily due to embolism of thrombotic material forming on the atrial or ventricular wall or the left heart valves. These thrombi then detach and embolize into the arterial circulation. The thrombus may fragment or lyse quickly, producing only a TIA. OR may last longer, producing a stroke. Embolic strokes tend to occur suddenly with maximum neurologic deficit present at onset. With reperfusion following more prolonged ischemia, petechial haemorrhages can occur within the ischemic territory. These are usually of no clinical significance and should be distinguished from frank intracranial haemorrhage into a region of the ischemic stroke where the mass effect from the haemorrhage can cause a significant decline in neurologic function. Emboli from the heart most often lodge in the intracranial internal carotid artery , the MCA , the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) , or one of their branches; infrequently, the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) is involved. Emboli large enough to occlude the stem of the MCA (3–4 mm) or internal carotid terminus lead to large infarcts that involve deep grey and white matter and some portions of the cortical surface and its underlying white matter. A smaller embolism may occlude a small cortical or penetrating arterial branch. The location and size of an infarct within a vascular territory depend on the extent of the collateral circulation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options B and C - CT brain and MRI/MRA will show the effect of the stroke and not the cause. Option D. Carotid doppler of carotid vessels- done to know underlying vascular disease.

Extraedge:

Investigation of a patient with an acute stroke Diagnostic question Investigation Is it a vascular lesion? CT/MRI Is it ischaemic or haemorrhagic? CT/MRI Is it a subarachnoid haemorrhage? CT/lumbar puncture Is there any cardiac source of embolism? Electrocardiogram (ECG) 24-hour ECG Echocardiogram What is the underlying vascular disease? Duplex ultrasound of carotids Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) CT angiography (CTA) Contrast angiography What are the risk factors? Full blood count Cholesterol Blood glucose Is there an unusual cause? Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) Serum protein electrophoresis Clotting/thrombophilia screen

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with an acute stroke . On examination, she has fluent speech with retained comprehension. She can write but cannot read what she has written. Naming is impaired. What is the most likely localisation of her stroke?
questions.correct_answer: C. Splenium of the corpus callosum
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Splenium of the corpus callosum This patient can write but they cannot read what they have written. This occurs from the loss of connections between visual input centres and language centres. Pure alexia without agraphia is a syndrome that occurs due to a lesion of the Splenium of the corpus callosum and medial occipital lobe mostly on the left side.

Highyeild:

Posterior cerebral artery - P1-Basilar bifurcation up to Post communicating artery. P2-Perimesencephalic cistern P3-Terminal part supplying calcarine fissure. P1 -supplies midbrain- Midbrain syndromes Thalamic -Dejerine Roussy syndrome Subthalamic - Contralateral hemiballismus P2- supplies temporal and occipital lobe. P1 segmental lesion- Weber’s syndrome Corticospinal tract affected -C/L hemiplegia 3rd nerve affected: I/L 3rd nerve palsy Substantia nigra affected: C/L Parkinson’s feature Claude syndrome Subthalamic nucleus lesion: C/L Hemiballismus Thalamic infarct→C/L hemisensory loss→ later burning pain in half of the body. Contralateral rhythmic, ataxic action tremor; rhythmic postural or “holding” tremor ( rubral tremor ): Dentatothalamic tract Allodynia: Pain from non-painful stimuli Hyperalgesia: Enhanced pain to mild painful stimuli P2 segmental lesion- Infarction of temporal(medial) and occipital lobe. Occipital lobe infarction: Memory impairment Visual agnosia for Face: Prosopagnosia Objects Colour abnormality Mathematical symbol abnormality Visual hallucination Anton’s syndrome- If visual association areas and primary areas are affected. B/L occlusion of PCA B/L occipital infarct Cortical blindness But the patient denies blindness. If B/L visual associations are affected by Balint’s syndrome Optic Ataxia Oculomotor Apraxia (difficult to lock and trace an object) Simultagnosia- The patient can’t see any complete image. The patient can see partially Left occipital+splenium fibres affected Alexia without agraphia C/L homonymous hemianopia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Angular gyrus - lesion results in anomic aphasia. Option A.Wenicke’s aphasia- occurs due to a lesion of the superior posterior temporal lobe. Option D. Broca's aphasia results from a lesion of the inferior frontal gyrus.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatic mitral valve disease has a history of atrial fibrillation. What are the recommended management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oral-acting anticoagulants (OAC) In this patient of Rheumatic mitral valve disease With atrial fibrillation ; OAC [ oral anticoagulant (VKA, thrombin inhibitor, or oral factor Xa inhibitors)] is the Prophylactic intervention to lower the risk of stroke overall.

Highyeild:

risk factors for stroke - Cardioembolic atrial fibrillation/flutter Myocardial Infarction valvular heart disease Cardiomyopathy for lacunar stroke and intraparenchymal haemorrhage Hypertension diabetes for all vascular mechanisms of stroke- Smoking Identification of modifiable risk factors and prophylactic interventions to lower risk is probably the best approach to stroke overall.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A.Observation and follow up -Patient is at high risk for stroke, therefore not recommended Option C. Aspirin-Aspirin is used in nonvalvular atrial fibrillation with a CHA2DS2VASc score of 0. Option D. OAC + aspirin- This combination does not provide any additional benefits and may increase the risk of bleeding. It’s recommended only if a patient of RHD gets Embolization or appendage clot despite OAC.

Extraedge:

Recommendations on Chronic Use of Antithrombotics for Various Cardiac Conditions CONDITION RECOMMENDATION Nonvalvular atrial fibrillation ● CHA 2 DS 2 -VASc score of 0 ● CHA 2 DS 2 -VASc score of 1 ● CHA 2 DS 2 -VASc score of ≥2 Calculate CHA 2 DS 2 -VASc score Aspirin or no antithrombotic Aspirin or OAC OAC Rheumatic mitral valve disease ● With atrial fibrillation, previous embolization, atrial appendage thrombus, or left atrial diameter >55 mm ● Embolization or appendage clot despite OAC OAC OAC plus aspirin Mitral valve prolapse ● Asymptomatic ● With otherwise cryptogenic stroke or TIA ● Atrial fibrillation No therapy Aspirin OAC Mitral annular calcification ● Without atrial fibrillation but systemic embolization, or otherwise cryptogenic stroke or TIA ● Recurrent embolization despite aspirin ● With atrial fibrillation Aspirin OAC OAC Aortic valve calcification ● Asymptomatic ● Otherwise cryptogenic stroke or TIA No therapy Aspirin Aortic arch mobile atheroma ● Otherwise cryptogenic stroke or TIA Aspirin or OAC Patent foramen ovale ● Otherwise cryptogenic ischemic stroke or TIA ● Indication for OAC (deep-venous thrombosis or hypercoagulable state) Aspirin or closure with the device OAC Mechanical heart value ● Aortic position, bileaflet or Medtronic Hall tilting disk with normal left atrial size and sinus rhythm ● Mitral position tilting disk or bileaflet valve ● Mitral or aortic position, anterior-apical myocardial infarct or left atrial enlargement ● Mitral or aortic position, with atrial fibrillation, hypercoagulable state, low ejection fraction, or atherosclerotic vascular disease ● Systemic embolization despite target INR VKA INR 2.5, range 2-3 VKA INR 3.0, range 2.5-3.5 VKA INR 3.0, range 2.5-3.5 Aspirin plus VKA INR 3.0, range 2.5-3.5 Add aspirin and/or increase INR: prior target was 2.5, increase to 3.0, range 2.5-3.5; the prior target was 3.0, increase to 3.5, range 3-4 Bioprosthetic valve ● No other indication for VKA therapy Aspirin Infective endocarditis Avoid antithrombotic agents Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis ● With systemic embolization Full-dose, unfractionated heparin or SC LMWH, or Xa inhibitor

questions.text: A 62-year-old is a known case of dyslipidemia, hypertension and chronic smoker with a 20-pack-year history. He also has a case of Non-valvular AF for which he is on oral metoprolol and dabigatran. He presents to the casualty with transient blurring of vision which subsequently resolves in 15 min on its own. MRI Brain done is normal. The Fundus examination done is normal. A diagnosis of TIA is considered. Which of the risk factors present in this patient has the HIGHEST Relative risk for stroke?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypertension This patient has had transient blurring of vision (amaurosis fugax) which has resolved in less than 1 hr. There is no evidence of infarction on brain imaging. Hence it is a case of Transient Ischemic attack.

Highyeild:

The Risk factors for stroke and their relative risk are shown in the table below- Risk Factors for Stroke RISK FACTOR RELATIVE RISK Hypertension 2-5 Atrial fibrillation 1.8-2.9 Diabetes 1.8-6 Smoking 1.8 Hyperlipidemia 1.8-2.6 Asymptomatic carotid stenosis 2.0 Symptomatic carotid stenosis (70-99%) Symptomatic carotid stenosis (50-69%)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B and C are not the highest risk factor for stroke. Option A. Smoking - relative risk for stroke is 8 %. Option B.Atrial fibrillation -relative risk for stroke is 8-2.9%. Option C. Dyslipidemia -relative risk for stroke is 1.8-2.6%.

Extraedge:

Risk of Stroke Following Transient Ischemic Attack: The ABCD2 Score CLINICAL FACTOR SCORE A: Age ≥60 years 1 B: SBP >140 mmHg or DBP >90 mmHg 1 C: Clinical symptoms Unilateral weakness 2 Speech disturbance without weakness 1 D: Duration >60 min 2 10-59 min 1 D: Diabetes (oral medications or insulin) 1 TOTAL SCORE SUM EACH CATEGORY ABCD 2 Score Total 3-Month Rate of Stroke (%) 0 0 1 2 2 3 3 3 4 8 5 12 6 17 7 22

questions.text: Consider the following statements The risk for stroke after a TIA is ~10-15% in the first 3 months with most events occurring in the first 2 days TIA is a contraindication to thrombolysis. CYP2C19 polymorphism leads to poor metabolism of aspirin and can lead to treatment failure when treated with a combination of Aspirin and A normal brain imaging study following TIA rules out a diagnosis of TIA Which of the following statements are false:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

3,4 Failure to respond to the combination of aspirin and clopidogrel is linked to the carriage of a common CYP2C19 polymorphism that leads to poor metabolism of clopidogrel ( Not aspirin as mentioned in the option) into its active form . Therefore statement 3 is a false statement. A normal brain imaging study following a TIA does not rule out TIA; rather, the clinical syndrome is diagnostic of TIA . Therefore statement 4 is a false statement.

Highyeild:

Transient Ischemic Attack(TIA)- TIAs are episode s of stroke symptoms that last only briefly; the standard definition of duration is <24 h, but most TIAs last <1 h . If a relevant brain infarction is identified on brain imaging, the clinical entity is now classified as a stroke regardless of the duration of symptoms. A normal brain imaging study following a TIA does not rule out TIA ; rather, the clinical syndrome is diagnostic . The causes of TIA are similar to the causes of ischemic stroke, but because TIAs may herald stroke, they are an important risk factor that should be considered separately and urgently. TIAs may arise from emboli to the brain or from in situ thrombosis of an intracranial vessel. With a TIA , the occluded blood vessel reopens and neurologic function is restored. The risk of stroke after a TIA is ~10–15% in the first 3 months , with most events occurring in the first 2 days. This risk can be directly estimated using the well-validated ABCD2 score. Therefore, urgent evaluation and treatment are justified. Because etiologies for stroke and TIA are identical, evaluation for TIA should parallel that of stroke. Significance of TIA- A significant percentage of patients develop full-blown strokes within the next 48 hours. High-risk stroke or any cardiovascular event within 90 days. The ABCD2 Score is a risk assessment tool designed to improve the prediction of short-term stroke risk after a transient ischemic attack (TIA). The score is optimized to predict the risk of stroke within 2 days after a TIA but also predicts stroke risk within 90 days. Risk of Stroke Following Transient Ischemic Attack: The ABCD2 Score table,tr,th,td {border:1px solid black;} CLINICAL FACTOR SCORE A: Age ≥60 years 1 B: SBP >140 mmHg or DBP >90 mmHg 1 C: Clinical symptoms Unilateral weakness 2 Speech disturbance without weakness 1 D: Duration >60 min 2 10-59 min 1 D: Diabetes (oral medications or insulin) 1 TOTAL SCORE SUM EACH CATEGORY ABCD 2 Score Total 3-Month Rate of Stroke (%) 0 0 1 2 2 3 3 3 4 8 5 12 6 17 7 22 Score>3: admitted and in-patient investigation did Score 0,1,2:Next 48 hr, do an investigation on an OPD basis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Statements 1 and 2 are correct statements about TIA. The risk for stroke after a TIA is ~10-15% in the first 3 months with most events occurring in the first 2 days . Hence statement 1 is a true statement The improvement characteristic of TIA is a contraindication to thrombolysis . Hence statement 2 is a true statement. Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

Extraedge:

Work up TIA- MRI Diffusion- weighted imaging Done within 24 hrs of symptoms onset. Non-invasive imaging ( Doppler ) of cervical cephalic vessels. ECG/ECHO done Management TIA Clopidogrel+Aspirin : Combination is a better but higher risk of Intracranial bleeding. Dual antiplatelet therapy is also beneficial to ABCD2 score>4 given about 21 days. On the 21st day of TIA: Dual antiplatelet therapy→ converted to single therapy

questions.text: 62 yrs old Raju known case of hypertension and diabetes presents with a Transient ischemic attack with a duration of 1.5 hrs, what is his risk of developing a stroke On examination: Systolic blood pressure – 148 mmHg?

options.label: A
options.text: Option 1 His risk of developing a stroke is 3% over 3 months

options.label: B
options.text: Option 2 his risk of developing a stroke is 3% over 4 months

options.label: C
options.text: Option 3 His risk of developing a stroke is 12% over 3 months

options.label: D
options.text: Option 4 His risk of developing a stroke is 12% over 4 months

questions.correct_answer: C. Option 3 His risk of developing a stroke is 12% over 3 months
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Option 3 His risk of developing a stroke is 12% over 3 months According to the ABCD2 score Age is more than 60 years – 1 H/o hypertension – 1 Duration of TIA > 60 mins – 2 H/o diabetes – 1 The total score is 5. Therefore, his risk of developing a stroke is 12% over 3 months

Highyeild:

The ABCD2 Score is a risk assessment tool designed to improve the prediction of short-term stroke risk after a transient ischemic attack (TIA). The score is optimized to predict the risk of stroke within 2 days after a TIA but also predicts stroke risk within 90 days. Risk of Stroke Following Transient Ischemic Attack: The ABCD2 Score CLINICAL FACTOR SCORE A: Age ≥60 years 1 B: SBP >140 mmHg or DBP >90 mmHg 1 C: Clinical symptoms Unilateral weakness 2 Speech disturbance without weakness 1 D: Duration >60 min 2 10-59 min 1 D: Diabetes (oral medications or insulin) 1 TOTAL SCORE SUM EACH CATEGORY ABCD 2 Score Total 3-Month Rate of Stroke (%) 0 0 1 2 2 3 3 3 4 8 5 12 6 17 7 22

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. is wrong According to the ABCD2 score Total score is 5 Options B and D are The risk of stroke following transient ischemic attack according to ABCD2 Score is taken as a 3-month rate of stroke (%).

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding the relationship between stroke and trials of statins to reduce the risk?

options.label: A
options.text: Statins only reduce the risk of stroke in patients with elevated LDL

options.label: C
options.text: Patients with low LDL caused by elevated C reactive protein are benefitted from statins

options.label: D
options.text: High level of LDL lowers the risk of recurrent stroke

questions.correct_answer: C. Patients with low LDL caused by elevated C reactive protein are benefitted from statins
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Patients with low LDL caused by elevated C reactive protein are benefitted from statins

Highyeild:

Identification and control of modifiable risk factors , and especially hypertension , is the best strategy to reduce the burden of stroke , and the total number of strokes could be reduced substantially by these means. Several trials have confirmed that statin drugs reduce the risk of stroke even in patients without elevated LDL or low HDL. The Stroke Prevention by Aggressive Reduction in Cholesterol Levels (SPARCL) trial showed benefit in secondary stroke reduction for patients with recent stroke or TIA who were prescribed atorvastatin, 80 mg/d. The primary prevention trial, Justification for the Use of Statins in Prevention: An Intervention Trial Evaluating Rosuvastatin (JUPITER) , found that patients with low LDL (<130 mg/dL) caused by elevated C-reactive protein benefitted by daily use of this statin. Primary stroke occurrence was reduced by 51% and there was no increase in the rates of intracranial haemorrhage. Meta-analysis has also supported a primary treatment effect for statins given acutely for ischemic stroke. A serum LDL <70 mg/dL lowers recurrent stroke risk better than an LDL of 90–110 mg/dL. Therefore, a statin should be considered in all patients with prior ischemic stroke.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Option A. Statins only reduce the risk of stroke in patients with elevated LDL-statin drugs reduce the risk of stroke even in patients without elevated LDL or low HDL. Option B. Trial is called SPRINT- J ustification for the U se of Statins in P revention: An I ntervention T rial E valuating R osuvastatin i s JUPITER trial . The Systolic Blood Pressure Intervention Trial ( SPRINT trial )suggest that lowering systolic blood pressure <120 mmHg reduces stroke and heart attack by 43% compared to systolic blood pressure <140 mmHg , without an increased risk of syncope or falls. Option D. High level of LDL lowers the risk of recurrent stroke- There is a well-established inverse relation between serum concentrations of HDL cholesterol and the risk of coronary heart disease ,but it is not a well-documented risk factor for stroke.

Extraedge:

Risk Factors for Stroke RISK FACTOR RELATIVE RISK RELATIVE RISK REDUCTION WITH TREATMENT Hypertension 2-5 38% Atrial fibrillation 1.8-2.9 68% warfarin, 21% aspirin Diabetes 1.8-6 No proven effect Smoking 1.8 50% at 1 year, baseline risk at 5 years post-cessation Hyperlipidemia 1.8-2.6 16-30% Asymptomatic carotid stenosis 2.0 53% Symptomatic carotid stenosis (70-99%) 65% at 2 years Symptomatic carotid stenosis (50-69%) 29% at 5 years

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding ischemic penumbra?

options.label: B
options.text: The ischemic penumbra will never progress to infarction

options.label: C
options.text: The penumbra can be imaged by perfusion imaging using MRI or CT

options.label: D
options.text: Saving the ischemic penumbra is the goal of revascularization therapies

questions.correct_answer: B. The ischemic penumbra will never progress to infarction
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The ischemic penumbra will never progress to infarction Lesser degrees of i schemia , as are seen within the ischemic penumbra which has not yet undergone irreversible infarction , implying that these regions are potentially salvageable if ischemia can be reversed . The Ischemic penumbra will eventually progress to Infarction if no change in flow occurs.

Highyeild:

Ischemic penumbra is defined as the ischemic but reversibly dysfunctional tissue surrounding a core area of infarction. That is areas of ischemic brain tissue that have not yet undergone irreversible infarction , implying that these regions are potentially salvageable if ischemia can be reversed . Factors that may exacerbate ischemic brain injury include systemic hypotension and hypoxia, which further reduce substrate delivery to vulnerable brain tissue, and fever, seizures, and hyperglycemia, which can increase cellular metabolism , outstripping compensatory processes. The penumbra can be imaged by perfusion imaging using MRI or CT. Predicted region of infarct (red) and penumbra (green) based on CT perfusion data. Focal cerebral infarction occurs via two distinct pathways (1) a necrotic pathway in which cellular cytoskeletal breakdown is rapid, due principally to energy failure of the cell and Without ATP, membrane ion pumps stop functioning and neurons depolarize , allowing intracellular calcium to rise. Cellular depolarization also causes glutamate release from synaptic terminals ; excess extracellular glutamate produces neurotoxicity by activating postsynaptic glutamate receptors that increase neuronal calcium influx. Ischemia also injures or destroys axons, dendrites, and glia within brain tissue. Free radicals are produced by degradation of membrane lipids and mitochondrial dysfunction. Free radicals cause catalytic destruction of membranes and likely damage other vital functions of Cells. (2) an apoptotic pathway in which cells become programmed to die. Ischemia produces necrosis by starving neurons of glucose and oxygen , which in turn results in failure of mitochondria to produce ATP. Lesser degrees of ischemia , as are seen within the ischemic penumbra , favor apoptotic cellular death, c ausing cells to die days to weeks later. The Ischemic penumbra will eventually progress to Infarction if no change in flow occurs, and hence, saving the ischemic penumbra is the goal of revascularization therapies.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C, and D are true regarding Ischemic Penumbra. Option A. It is reversible- ischemic penumbra which has not yet undergone irreversible infarction , implying that these regions are potentially salvageable if ischemia can be reversed . Option C. The penumbra can be imaged by perfusion imaging using MRI or CT-. CT perfusion imaging increases the sensitivity for detecting ischemia and can measure the ischemic penumbra. Alternatively, MR perfusion can be combined with MR diffusion imaging to identify the ischemic penumbra as the mismatch between these two imaging sequences. Option D. Saving the ischemic penumbra is the goal of revascularization therapies- Current evidence-based treatments involve restoration of blood flow so as to salvage the penumbra before it evolves into irreversibly damaged tissue, termed the 'core'. Intravenous thrombolysis (IVT) can salvage the penumbra if given within 4.5 hr after stroke onset. Without specific therapy, the region of infarction will expand into much or all the perfusion deficit.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atrial fibrillation Relative risk reduction of atrial fibrillation with warfarin is 68% which is the highest.

Highyeild:

Risk Factors for Stroke RISK FACTOR RELATIVE RISK RELATIVE RISK REDUCTION WITH TREATMENT Hypertension 2-5 38% Atrial fibrillation 1.8-2.9 68% warfarin, 21% aspirin Diabetes 1.8-6 No proven effect Smoking 1.8 50% at 1 year, baseline risk at 5 years post-cessation Hyperlipidemia 1.8-2.6 16-30% Asymptomatic carotid stenosis 2.0 53% Symptomatic carotid stenosis (70-99%) 65% at 2 years Symptomatic carotid stenosis (50-69%) 29% at 5 years

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C, and D also have relative risk reduction on prophylaxis but the reduction is less as compared to atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: 60 yrs old man, presents with sudden unilateral paralysis of face and arm, with troubled speaking As an intern, You suspect transient ischemic attack Which of the following statements are correct regarding the same? a) TIA lasts < 24 hrs b) Normal brain imaging study rules out TIA c) Risk of stroke after TIA is 10-15% in the first three months d) ABCD2 score is used to assess the risk of stroke Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a,c,d a,c, and d are correct statements about TIA. Statement a)TIAs are episodes of stroke symptoms that last only briefly; the standard definition of duration is <24 h , but most TIAs last <1 h. Statement b) is incorrect. A normal brain imaging study following a TIA does not rule out TIA; rather, the clinical syndrome is diagnostic. Statement c) The risk of stroke after a TIA is ~10–15% in the first 3 months , with most events occurring in the first 2 days. Statement d) The ABCD2 Score is a risk assessment tool designed to improve the prediction of short-term stroke risk after a transient ischemic attack (TIA).

Highyeild:

Transient Ischemic Attack(TIA)- TIAs are episode s of stroke symptoms that last only briefly; the standard definition of duration is <24 h, but most TIAs last <1 h . If a relevant brain infarction is identified on brain imaging, the clinical entity is now classified as a stroke regardless of the duration of symptoms. A normal brain imaging study following a TIA does not rule out TIA ; rather, the clinical syndrome is diagnostic . The causes of TIA are similar to the causes of ischemic stroke, but because TIAs may herald stroke, they are an important risk factor that should be considered separately and urgently. TIAs may arise from emboli to the brain or from in situ thrombosis of an intracranial vessel. With a TIA , the occluded blood vessel reopens and neurologic function is The risk of stroke after a TIA is ~10–15% in the first 3 months , with most events occurring in the first 2 days. This risk can be directly estimated using the well-validated ABCD2 score. Therefore, urgent evaluation and treatment are justified. Because etiologies for stroke and TIA are identical, evaluation for TIA should parallel that of Significance of TIA- A significant percentage of patients develop full-blown strokes within the next 48 hours. High-risk stroke or any cardiovascular event within 90 days. The ABCD2 Score is a risk assessment tool designed to improve the prediction of short-term stroke risk after a transient ischemic attack (TIA). The score is optimized to predict the risk of stroke within 2 days after a TIA but also predicts stroke risk within 90 days.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Neuroprotection is the concept of providing a treatment that prolongs the brain's tolerance to ischemia. Identify the incorrect statement about neuroprotection.

options.label: A
options.text: Drugs that block the excitatory amino acid pathways have been shown to protect neurons

options.label: B
options.text: Hypothermia is a powerful neuroprotective treatment in cardiac arrest patients

options.label: C
options.text: Hypothermia with hemicraniectomy is more effective than euthermia

options.label: D
options.text: Hypothermia is associated with increased pneumonia rates

questions.correct_answer: C. Hypothermia with hemicraniectomy is more effective than euthermia
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypothermia with hemicraniectomy is more effective than euthermia Hypothermia with hemicraniectomy is more effective than hemicraniectomy with euthermia is an incorrect statement.As trials have proven that Hypothermia combined with hemicraniectomy is no more effective than hemicraniectomy with euthermia.

Highyeild:

Focal cerebral infarction occurs via two distinct pathways (1) a necrotic pathway in which cellular cytoskeletal breakdown is rapid, due principally to energy failure of the cell and Without ATP, membrane ion pumps stop functioning and neurons depolarize, allowing intracellular calcium to rise. Cellular depolarization also causes glutamate release from synaptic terminals; excess extracellular glutamate produces neurotoxicity by activating postsynaptic glutamate receptors that increase neuronal calcium influx. Ischemia also injures or destroys axons, dendrites, and glia within brain tissue. Free radicals are produced by degradation of membrane lipids and mitochondrial dysfunction. Free radicals cause catalytic destruction of membranes and likely damage other vital functions of cells. (2) an apoptotic pathway in which cells become programmed to die. Ischemia produces necrosis by starving neurons of glucose and oxygen, which in turn results in failure of mitochondria to produce ATP. Lesser degrees of ischemia, as are seen within the ischemic penumbra , favor apoptotic cellular death, c ausing cells to die days to weeks later. The Ischemic penumbra will eventually progress to Infarction if no change in flow occurs, and hence, saving the ischemic penumbra is the goal of revascularization therapies. Neuroprotection is the concept of providing a treatment that prolongs the brain’s tolerance to ischemia. Drugs that block the excitatory amino acid pathways have been shown to protect neurons and glia in animals, but despite multiple human trials, they have not yet been proven to be beneficial. Fever dramatically worsens brain injury during ischemia , as does hyperglycemia (glucose >11.1 mmol/L [200 mg/dL]) , so it is reasonable to suppress fever and prevent hyperglycemia as much as possible. The value of induced mild hypothermia to improve stroke outcomes is the subject of continuing clinical research. Hypothermia is a powerful neuroprotective treatment in patients with cardiac arrest and is neuroprotective in animal models of stroke, but it has not been adequately studied in patients with ischemic stroke and is associated with an increase in pneumonia rates that could adversely impact stroke outcomes. Hypothermia combined with hemicraniectomy is no more effective than hemicraniectomy with euthermia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B and D are correct statements. Option A. Drugs that block the excitatory amino acid pathways have been shown to protect neurons and glia in animals ( glutamate is an excitatory amino acid in the brain , excess extracellular glutamate produces neurotoxicity by activating postsynaptic glutamate receptors that increase neuronal calcium influx worsening necrotic cell injury). But despite multiple human trials, they have not yet been proven to be beneficial. Option B. Hypothermia is a powerful neuroprotective treatment in cardiac arrest patients as proven by research but it has not been adequately studied in patients with ischemic stroke. Option D. Hypothermia is associated with an increase in pneumonia rates that could adversely impact stroke outcomes.

questions.text: You diagnose stroke in a patient in an emergency, the correct sequence for the management of stroke is a) Treating hypoglycemia b) Attention to the patient's airway, breathing and circulation c) Performing MRI d) Performing CT scan Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

b→a→d b→a→d This is a correct sequence for the management of stroke . Because in an emergency, Airway,breathing & circulation is first priority, followed by blood glucose then NCCT is done to rule out any hemorrhage so that one can proceed with Thrombolysis as soon as possible if indicated. Step c.MRI is not used in the initial evaluation as it has a longer scanning time.

Highyeild:

Patient with acute ischemic stroke- Airway-Breathing-Circulation Blood glucose NCCT-rule out haemorrhage BP evaluation: Target <185/110 for Thrombolytic therapy (Labetalol, Nicardipine,clevidipine) Thrombolytic therapy Contraindicated in age <18 yr Previously the only allowed thrombolytic was Alteplase. Drawback-given over 1 hr In Covid era Tenecteplase Can be given over 2 min If a patient comes after 4.5 hr CT Angio/MR angio with perfusion studies→ Patient with large vessel occlusion → Mechanical embolectomy (done upto 24 hr) Mechanical Embolectomy It used Retriever stent: TREVO stent (2nd generation ) FIGURE 426-1 Medical management of stroke and TIA. Rounded boxes are diagnoses; rectangles are interventions. Numbers are percentages of strokes overall. ABCs, airway, breathing, circulation; BP, blood pressure; CEA, carotid endarterectomy, ICH, intracerebral haemorrhage; SAH, subarachnoid haemorrhage; TIA, transient ischemic attack.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C, and D are incorrect sequences. Option A. a→d→b- In any emergency, Airway,breathing & circulation is first priority Option C.Directly c- We can not go to investigations directly without managing Airway,breathing & circulation. Also, MRI Brain is not used in stroke patients for initial evaluation as it is time consuming. Option D.d→b→a→c- In any emergency, Airway,breathing & circulation is first priority.

questions.text: Identify the correct statements regarding medical support given to patients with ischemic stroke a) Blood pressure is reduced If it exceeds 180/100 b) Lowering the heart rate with B1 adrenergic blocker c) Fever should be treated immediately d) Routine blood pressure reduction is detrimental Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

b c d statements are correct statements regarding medical support given to patients with Ischemic stroke Statement b) When faced with competing demands of the myocardium and brain lowering heart rate with B1 adrenergic blockers is the first step to decrease cardiac work and maintain BP. Statement c) Fever should be treated immediately .fever is detrimental and should be immediately treated with antipyretics Statement d) Routine blood pressure reduction is detrimental This is a correct statement. The aim is to maintain BP on a higher side such that any impacted thrombus or emboli may pass into the bloodstream with the flow of blood.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Statement a) Blood pressure is reduced If it exceeds 180/100 This is a wrong statement- Blood pressure is reduced if it exceeds 220/120 mmHg - The aim is to maintain BP on a higher side such that any impacted thrombus or emboli may pass in the bloodstream with the flow of blood. Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Aspirin is the only antiplatelet agent with proven benefit for the acute treatment of ischemic stroke Which of the following statements are true?

options.label: A
options.text: Aspirin administration within 48 hrs of stroke onset reduces both stroke recurrence risk and mortality

options.label: B
options.text: Combining aspirin with clopidogrel following a minor stroke is effective at preventing a second stroke

options.label: C
options.text: For every 1000 acute strokes treated with aspirin, ~ 9 deaths or nonfatal stroke recurrences will be prevented in the first few weeks

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above is true about the benefit of Oral Antiplatelet agents for the Acute treatment of ischemic stroke.

Highyeild:

Antithrombotic treatment Platelet inhibition- Aspirin is the only antiplatelet agent that has been proven to be effective for the acute treatment of ischemic stroke Two large trials, the International Stroke Trial (IST) and the Chinese Acute Stroke Trial (CAST), found that the use of aspirin within 48 hr of stroke onset reduced both stroke recurrence risk and mortality minimally. These trials demonstrate that the use of aspirin in the treatment of Acute Ischemic Stroke is safe and produces a small net benefit. For every 1000 acute strokes treated with aspirin, ~9 deaths or nonfatal stroke recurrences will be prevented in the first few weeks and ~13 fewer patients will be dead or dependent at 6 months. Combining aspirin with clopidogrel or with ticagrelor following a minor stroke or TIA is effective at preventing a second stroke.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B, C -option D is more correct than individual options.

Extraedge:

Drugs to be avoided in stroke- Nitroprusside Nitroglycerine Clonidine Methyldopa

questions.text: Food and Drug Administration approved the use of IV-rtPA for patients with AIS presenting within 3 h of symptom onset Correct statement about rtPA administration is:

options.label: A
options.text: At 0- to 4.5-h time window, non-contrast head computed tomography (CT) is the only required imaging

options.label: B
options.text: If large vessel occlusion is suspected, computed tomography angiogram (CTA) can be obtained simultaneously, only if it does not delay treatment with IV-rtPA

options.label: C
options.text: Treatment with IV-rtPA can be considered, even with a history of seizure at the onset, if residual impairments are thought to be from stroke

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. NCCT is required to rule out bleeding before giving iv -rtPA. Option B. During treatment of Ischemic stroke after doing NCCT and ruling out ha Thrombolysis should not be delayed for any other investigation. Option C. Seizure is not a contraindication for Thrombolysis.

Highyeild:

Administration of Intravenous Recombinant Tissue Plasminogen Activator (rtPA) for Acute Ischemic Stroke (AIS) a INDICATION CONTRAINDICATION Clinical diagnosis of stroke Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration ≤4.5 h b CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3 of the MCA territory Age ≥18 years Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment Bleeding diathesis Recent head injury or intracerebral haemorrhage Major surgery in preceding 14 days Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days Recent myocardial infarction Administration of rtPA IV access with two peripheral IV lines (avoid arterial or central line placement) Review eligibility for rtPA Administer 0.9 mg/kg IV (maximum 90 mg) IV as 10% of total dose by bolus, followed by the remainder of total dose over 1 h c Frequent cuff BP monitoring No other antithrombotic treatment for 24 h For the decline in neurologic status or uncontrolled BP, stop an infusion, give cryoprecipitate, and reimage brain emergently Avoid urethral catheterization for ≥2 h "See Activase (tissue plasminogen activator) package insert for a complete list of contraindications and dosing. 'Depending on the country, IV rtPA may be approved for up to 4.5 h with additional restrictions. A dose of 0.6 mg/kg is commonly used in Asia (Japan and China) based on randomized data indicating less haemorrhage and similar efficacy using this lower dose. Abbreviations: BP, blood pressure; CT, computed tomography; MCA, middle cerebral artery.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, B, C -option D is more correct than individual options.

questions.text: Immediate specific management depends on the time of arrival of the patients after the onset of symptoms and the severity of the stroke. Following are correct statements regarding the management of ischemic stroke: A) Patients with acute ischemic stroke who are allergic to or intolerant of aspirin should Be given an alternative antiplatelet agent. B) acute stroke patients should be given at least 150 mg of plain aspirin immediately after excluding intracranial haemorrhage with neuroimaging C) In dysphagic patients, Aspirin may be given by an enteral tube. D) Patients with acute ischemic stroke and a contraindication to intravenous thrombolysis should be considered for intra-arterial clot extraction Select the correct answer from the given below code:

options.label: D
options.text: If all the above is correct

questions.correct_answer: D. If all the above is correct
questions.explanation:
Solution:

If all the above is correct

Highyeild:

Management of ischemic stroke- All patients with a measurable neurological deficit after acute ischemic stroke who can be treated within 4.5 hours after symptom onset should be evaluated without delay to determine their eligibility for treatment with a thrombolytic agent. Patients with acute ischemic stroke should be considered for a combination of intravenous thrombolysis and intra-arterial clot extraction (using stent retriever and/or aspiration techniques ) if they have Internal carotid or proximal middle cerebral artery occlusion causing a disabling neurological deficit and the patient can be referred to a tertiary healthcare facility, where the procedure can begin (arterial puncture) within 24 hours of last known attack. Patients with acute ischemic strok e and a contraindication to intravenous thrombolysis but not to thrombectomy should be considered for intra-arterial clot extraction (using stent retriever and/or aspiration techniques) if they have internal carotid or proximal middle cerebral artery occlusion causing a disabling neurological deficit and the patient can be referred to a tertiary healthcare facility, where the procedure can begin (arterial puncture) within 24 hours of last known well. All acute stroke patients should be given at least 150 mg of plain aspirin immediately after excluding intracranial haemorrhage with neuroimaging (in patients receiving thrombolysis, aspirin should be delayed until after the 24-hour post-thrombolysis). allergic to or intolerant of aspirin an alternative antiplatelet agent (e.g. clopidogrel). In patients with large hemispheric infarct [malignant middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory infarct] aspirin may be delayed until surgery. Aspirin may be started after a decision is made not to operate. In dysphagic patients, Aspirin may be given by an enteral tube. For non-cardio embolic stroke , aspirin (at least 75 mg) should be continued as Indicated in ‘secondary prevention’. Any patient with acute ischemic stroke who is known to have dyspepsia with aspirin Should be given a proton pump inhibitor in addition to aspirin .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B, C -Option D is the better answer.

Extraedge:

'Depending on the country, IV rtPA may be approved for up to 4.5 h with additional restrictions. A dose of 0.6 mg/kg is commonly used in Asia (Japan and China) based on randomized data indicating less haemorrhage and similar efficacy using this lower dose. Abbreviations: BP, blood pressure; CT, computed tomography; MCA, middle cerebral artery.
